awd_titl_txt: Gendered Elective Track Choices in Engineering Undergraduate Education: Antecedents and Career Path Implications
awd_abstract_narration:
Research has shown that women who pursue engineering careers are more likely than their male counterparts to be in less technical roles and careers paths, such as business analysis, technical supervision, and product management.  In addition, these gendered career patterns increase attrition risk for female engineers. This project aims to serve the national interest of broadening participation by improving the representation of women in technically-oriented roles and career paths within engineering. This Institutional and Community Transformation, Exploration and Design project focuses on female engineering students' elective track choices as a predictor of gendered career patterns.  Project personnel will investigate the driving forces behind elective track choices for female engineering students.  Then, they will use the findings to inform faculty development and other administrative efforts to improve gender balance within technical elective tracks and technically-oriented careers.  
 
The goal of the project is to identify individual and institutional factors that contribute to female students' elective track choices within engineering majors. This study builds on previous work that demonstrates gendered role and career patterns, and will contribute to filling gaps in understanding how and why these patterns develop.  The investigators will collect data over multiple years through surveys and interviews of female undergraduates in engineering.  The study will also include faculty and staff members who advise those students regarding elective track selection. The surveys will be developed by the PIs and will incorporate previously validated measures of math attitudes, role confidence, engineering identity, and related constructs.  Using a longitudinal, multi-method and multi-level case study approach, the investigators will identify key relationships between female students' elective track choices and institutional demographics, culture, curriculum, and instructional approaches in both gender-balanced and imbalanced majors. The study, which includes oversight from an external evaluator, will produce recommendations for engineering faculty, advisors, and administrators who can directly affect the climate of engineering programs and career path decisions of engineering students. Moreover, the findings may inform similar investigations of gendered educational tracking in non-engineering majors (e.g., mathematics; physics), and may generalize to other educational settings beyond the study site. Thus, the study could help address gendered practices and identify strategies to minimize them throughout undergraduate STEM education.  This project is supported by the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program (IUSE): Education and Human Resources (EHR).  The IUSE Program supports projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all undergraduate students. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, IUSE : EHR program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Institutional and Community Transformation: Exploration and Design category project explored a novel approach to creating balanced and inclusive engineering undergraduate education and broadening the participation of women in engineering generally, and in technical career paths in engineering in particular. The purpose of the research was to better understand the gendering of undergraduate track election choices in engineering majors, with the goal of understanding how to improve the representation of women in more technically-oriented career paths. We focused on elective track selection as an early or “upstream” antecedent to critical role and career path choices among female engineers. In particular, the project sought to understand women’s elective track decisions in engineering undergraduate training, as well as whether and how they might shape women students’ career-related decisions and attitudes. We examined the personal and structural factors contributing to these elective track decisions and career attitudes, as well as the implications of track selection for career-relevant outcomes.

 

The study applied longitudinal case study analysis to understand and compare women engineering students’ track selection and early career attitudes and decisions in three engineering subdisciplines—biomedical engineering, computer science, and electrical engineering. These disciplines were selected based on high, medium and low representation of women at the focal institution. The flexibility of the case study design allowed multiple types of data collection, including quantitative, qualitative and institutional data. In particular, we collected three waves of interview data, two waves of survey data and institutional data gender representation and elective track decisions.  

 

The results of the project, disseminated in several published studies, provide insight into women engineers’ career-relevant elective track choices and career decision-making during undergraduate education, and how each might inform the transition from education settings to the workforce, as well as gendered career patterns in engineering. Key results include: (1) the identification of the critical factors (including curricular, extracurricular, programmatic, personal and peer) contributing to women engineers’ elective track selection; (2) the identification of women engineering preconceptions about career paths in engineering and potential reasons for interest in pursuing less technical career paths; and (3) students consider non-technical career paths in engineering; (3) identification of, and exploration of gender differences in, engineering students’ outcome expectations and career sector interests associated with elective track selection. In addition, to advancing scholarly knowledge in these areas, results from this research can help engineering education institutions to become aware of hidden gendering in their educational systems and understand strategies to address it.

The ultimate aim of this project was to have an impact of broadening participation of women in engineering by developing insights and conceptual models related to how and why women engineering students make decisions about elective tracks in engineering education and career paths in engineering, as well as how these decisions might affect their future careers.

To this aim, the study has produced research insights and recommendations for engineering faculty, advisors, and administrators who can directly affect the climate of engineering programs as well as the career path decisions of women engineers.

 


Last Modified: 09/20/2023
Modified by: Maria T Cardador
